title: Imported produce and local standards
vignette: A distributor imports apples from overseas orchards where their maturity date is unclear. In the local market, should retailers assume these apples are unripe and refuse to sell them, or treat them as marketable unless proven otherwise?

options.text: Refuse sale; apply local strict maturity standards.
Allow sale; treat imported produce leniently until issues are confirmed.

title: Sale of third-year orchard produce
vignette: A farmer’s orchard has just entered its third year of growth. Regulations forbid selling produce from orchards younger than three years. May he now sell this year’s fruit to recoup his expenses?

options.text: Prohibit sale; no benefit allowed until full period.
Allow sale to external customers; regulation applies only locally.

title: Cross-border fruit picking
vignette: An orchard straddles the border between Country A and Country B: its roots are in Country A, but branches hang over into Country B. A visitor in Country B picks fruit from the overhanging branches. Should that fruit be treated by Country A’s restrictions or Country B’s rules?

options.text: Apply Country A’s restrictions—status follows the root location.
Apply Country B’s rules—status follows the place of picking.

title: Uncertain maturity of purchased orchard
vignette: A buyer acquires an orchard without age records; the trees might still be within the restricted growth period. Should he assume the fruit is restricted until proven mature, or treat it as permitted until shown otherwise?

options.text: Assume restricted until maturity is proven.
Assume permitted until restriction is proven.

title: Contaminated batch and nullification
vignette: One crate of prohibited figs accidentally falls into 300 identical crates. Must all crates be destroyed, or can the contamination be considered nullified if the ratio meets a threshold?

options.text: Destroy all crates—no nullification for prohibited items.
Permit sale if ratio ≥1:200, nullifying the contamination.

title: Using prohibited shells as fuel
vignette: A baker considers burning nut shells—previously deemed prohibited—in his oven for fuel. May he benefit from the heat produced?

options.text: Prohibit any benefit from their heat.
Permit after burning; residual ashes lose prohibition.

title: Using prohibited husks for dye
vignette: A textile artist boils husks from prohibited fruit to produce dye. May the resulting fabric be sold?

options.text: Fabric remains forbidden—benefit continues.
Fabric permitted—benefit ended when processed.

title: Feeding prohibited produce to livestock
vignette: A farmer considers feeding prohibited dates to his livestock. Is that disallowed, or only direct human consumption is banned?

options.text: Forbidden—animal feed counts as benefit.
Permitted—only direct human use is banned.

title: Use of ash from prohibited wood
vignette: An arborist burns restricted wood into ash. May the ash be used as fertilizer?

options.text: Yes; prohibition ends once turned to ash.
No; residual benefit remains forbidden.

title: Retroactive dilution effect
vignette: A small amount of prohibited wine is mixed with permissible wine at a ratio below 1:200. Later, more permissible wine is added. Does this addition retroactively nullify the initial prohibition?

options.text: Yes; later dilution nullifies the prohibition.
No; it was prohibited from the start.
